entry.title: Issue with Adopt UI ‚Äì "Publish" Button Disabled for Custom Field in Sales Order Workflow
entry.content:
Dear Expert

I am facing an issue in the Flexible Workflow for Sales Orders in our SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud system.

I have added a custom field "User Remarks" using Custom Fields and Logic, which is used in the workflow for managerial approval. The field is successfully visible when I try to add it using Adopt UI, but the "Active New Version" and Publish Version" buttons remain greyed out, so I am unable to activate or use this field in the workflow screen.

Steps taken:

  1. Created a custom field "User Remarks" in the Sales Document context.
  2. Enabled it for the relevant UI and workflow scenarios.
  3. Tried to add it in the UI via Adaptation Mode (Adopt UI).
  4. The field appears, but Publish is disabled, blocking further progress.
  5. This is impacting our internal sales approval process, where remarks are required before the manager approves the order.

Could you please assist or advise if there‚Äôs a missing configuration or limitation?

The issue has been highlighted in green colour

entry.title: Succession Org Chart Reporting
entry.content:
Hello! We are using position-based SOC (succession org chart) WITHOUT position management. We are trying to see if there is a way to capture periodic reporting snapshots of the SOC if vacant positions drop off due to the intricacies that happen with our org chart sync process.

Has anyone found the ability to take snapshots of the SOC through Report Center? The fields there seem limited, Specifically, we want to capture through a report vacant positions and their successors before they inadvertently drop off the SOC due to timing issues and other things unique to the sync process.

A periodic reporting snapshot would help this, but there doesn't seem to be the full field set to do so. Any ideas? Again, the root problem we are trying to solve for is when vacant position tiles drop off, and we need to restore them manually. Need a report to tell us what specific information to restore for that tile that dropped off.

We are also in the midst of troubleshooting our succession org chart sync process. Is there a call anytime with this group to exchange experiences and learn best practices that other customers have had troubleshooting their SOC data and keeping it clean?

entry.title: Queue Browser: Deep Message Visibility for Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite
entry.content:
Introduction

In event-driven architectures, messages flow continuously between systems, carrying critical business data and triggering essential processes. When something goes wrong‚Äîmessages pile up, integrations fail, or data appears corrupted‚Äîyou need immediate visibility into what‚Äôs happening inside your queues. Without this insight, troubleshooting becomes a frustrating game of guesswork.

Monitoring message queues is essential in event‚Äëdriven architectures. It reveals queue health and uncovers bottlenecks, providing crucial delivery and routing insights that ensure system reliability. With the latest release of Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite, we‚Äôre excited to announce Queue Browser, a new capability that delivers deep message visibility through an intuitive web‚Äëbased interface.

The key advantage: Visualizing and inspecting messages using Queue Browser won't consume them from the message broker queue, so you can safely examine message metadata‚Äîsuch as headers, statuses, and errors‚Äîand troubleshoot malformed payloads without disrupting live processing.

What is Queue Browser in Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite?

Queue Browser is a web-based monitoring and diagnostics tool that allows you to inspect messages in a queue without consuming them from the message broker queue. Think of it as a "read-only window" into your message queues‚Äîyou can see everything that's happening without affecting the actual message flow.

Queue Browser bridges the gap between high-level queue metrics and detailed application logs, giving you the message-level insight needed for effective troubleshooting.

Key Capabilities

  • Search & Filter: Quickly locate messages by criteria such as message ID, correlation ID, and custom properties.
  • Header, Payload, and Custom Properties Inspection: View standard JMS-style headers (timestamp, delivery mode, Dead Message Queue eligibility) and examine the message payload alongside any custom properties. This is invaluable for validating data transformations and ensuring message integrity.
  • Message Management: Identify and inspect stuck or problematic messages in queues, with the option to delete them when needed.
  • Purge Queues: Clear all messages from a selected queue in one action, ideal for resetting test environments or clearing backed-up queues during maintenance.

Queue Browser in action

Accessing the Queue Browser

Step 1: Navigate to Queue Monitoring

In the SAP Integration Suite Cockpit, open the left‚Äëhand menu and navigate to:

Monitor ‚Ä∫ Event Mesh ‚Ä∫ Queues

Step 2: Review Queue Metrics

You‚Äôll see a comprehensive table listing all your queues with real-time usage metrics:

Monitoring Event Mesh Usage ‚Äì Queue List Floorplan

  • Name: The name of the queue
  • Messages Queued: Number of messages in the queue
  • Unacknowledged Messages: Number of unacknowledged messages in the queue. Messages delivered but not yet acknowledged as processed.
  • Queue Size: The queue size in bytes.
  • Max Queue Size: The maximum size possible for the queue in bytes.

These metrics provide immediate insight into queue health‚Äîhigh unacknowledged message counts often indicate processing issues, while queues approaching their size limits may need attention.

Step 3: Drill Down to Message List

Message List Report Floorplan

Select any queue to drill down to its message list page, where you can view some per‚Äëmessage information:

  • Message ID: Identifier for tracking messages
  • Correlation ID: Identifier to trace the request journey
  • Time Sent: Time the message was sent
  • Message Size: The size of the message content, in bytes
  • Redelivered: Indicates if the message was redelivered or not‚Äîa key troubleshooting indicator
  • Destination: Destination of the message
  • DMQ Eligible: Indicates whether the message is eligible for the Dead Message Queue (DMQ)

Step 4: Inspect Individual Messages

Message Details ‚Äì Object Page Floorplan

Click a message entry to navigate to its details page. The level of access depends on your assigned roles:

Users can review the message headers by default; if your BTP user has the EventMeshBusinessExpert role collection assigned, you‚Äôll also see the full payload and any custom properties.

Security Note: Access to single‚Äëmessage inspection is restricted to specific roles only. Only users assigned the EventMeshBusinessExpert role collection should be granted permission to view full message payloads and custom properties and delete messages. This ensures that message access is tightly controlled per organizational requirements and can be managed via Configuring User Access.

Message Detail Components

Headers Information

  • Identifiers
    • Message ID: Identifier for tracking messages
    • Correlation ID: Identifier to trace the request journey
  • Delivery Information
    • Time Sent: Time the message was sent
    • Redelivered: Indicates if the message was redelivered or not‚Äîa key troubleshooting indicator
    • Delivery Mode: The mode which is used for message delivery
  • Routing Information
    • Destination: The destination of the message
    • Reply To: The address or topic to which the recipient should send the response, when a message that requires a reply or acknowledgment, is published.
    • DMQ Eligible: Indicates whether the message is eligible for the Dead Message Queue (DMQ)
  • Additional Information: Message size in bytes

Payload

The message payload contains the actual business data being transmitted between systems.

Custom Properties

Custom properties contain business-specific metadata that applications attach to messages. These might include:

  • Customer IDs for filtering
  • Source system identifiers for tracing

This metadata is invaluable for understanding message context and implementing sophisticated filtering strategies.

Available Actions

From the message detail page, users with appropriate permissions can:

  • Delete individual problematic messages
  • Download message payloads for offline analysis
  • Copy message IDs and correlation IDs for use in other tools

Conclusion

The Queue Browser for Event Mesh in SAP Integration Suite transforms how you monitor and troubleshoot event-driven systems. By providing safe, non-disruptive message inspection, it empowers you to validate message content before processing, diagnose complex integration issues, and ensure smooth data flow.

Next Steps

  1. Explore Queue Browser in your SAP Integration Suite tenant‚Äînavigate to Monitor ‚Ä∫ Event Mesh ‚Ä∫ Queues
  2. Review the official documentation:
    • Monitor Event Mesh
    • Configuring User Access
    • Personas & Permissions
  3. Share your experience on the SAP Community‚Äîhelp others understand how Queue Browser improves their troubleshooting workflows

Queue Browser puts the visibility and control you need right at your fingertips. Start exploring your message queues today and experience the difference that comprehensive message visualization and inspection makes in maintaining event-driven architectures.

Happy monitoring!

entry.title: Why the Future of SAP Consulting Delivery Is More Human
entry.content:
For years, SAP Consulting delivery has been seen as a technical and structured exercise: timelines, modules, go-lives, KPIs. But that view is no longer enough. The projects that fail today do not fail because of technical errors, they fail due to a lack of connection, empathy, and emotional leadership.
Success in consulting delivery is no longer just about what is delivered, but how people experience it, those who execute it and those who receive it.
In the context of S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition implementations, where speed, standardization, fit-to-standard and early adoption are essential, the human component becomes even more critical. The agility that this model demands cannot be achieved by technology alone, it requires teams and leaders who can manage uncertainty, enable rapid change, and support users through their adaptation journey to cloud technology.
Cloud-based projects require clear communication, empathetic leadership, and strong emotional management to ensure that transformation is not only implemented but successfully adopted and embraced. In this environment, emotional intelligence and executive coaching are not ‚Äúnice to haves‚Äù‚Äîthey are core skills to maximize delivery value.
In my role as a Senior SAP ERP Cloud Consultant, specialized in Finance (Management Accounting, Asset Accounting, Budget Control, and Financial Projects), I have led complex projects across Latin America.
I am also an Executive Coach in Emotional Intelligence and Neuro Linguistic Programming and I‚Äôve seen first-hand that when we apply human tools to delivery:
‚Ä¢‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉTeams perform better, with less burnout.
‚Ä¢‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉClients feel understood, not managed.
‚Ä¢‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉTrust becomes a competitive advantage.

The SAP Consulting delivery of the future will be:
‚Ä¢‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉTechnical + Human
‚Ä¢‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉStructurally rigorous + Emotionally intelligent
‚Ä¢‚ÄÉ‚ÄÉProcess-based + People-powered

If we want more agile organizations, more strategic consultants, and more engaged clients, we need leaders who listen, support, connect, and communicate with humanity.
Because the system we implement matters.
But the system we are as people, is what truly transforms.
And you? Are you leading in a more human way?

entry.title: On the Manage Purchase Order app, logic to determine the Create Purchase Order - Advance app?
entry.content:
On the Manage Purchase Order app, how does the system determine the Create Purchase Order - Advanced app?

What's the logic to open a particular PO in "Fiori app" vs. "Create Purchase Order - Advanced app"?

What do I need to change to ensure that all my POs are open in "Fiori App"

 

SAP Helps says that "if a purchase order has a feature that is not supported...." But the question is, which features are not supported?

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_S4HANA_ON-PREMISE/af9ef57f504840d2b81be8667206d485/28f492016a52485784d85b7a31f7542d.html

If a purchase order has a feature that is not supported by the Fiori app, this is indicated by the icon "i" (='Advanced' Purchase Order) in the list. In this case, you can jump directly from the list in the Manage Purchase Orders app to the relevant purchase order that is then opened automatically in the classic Create Purchase Order - Advanced app.

Hello @Giacomo_Savioli 

You're right, custom Situation Handling objects are not yet available in SAP S/4HANA Public cloud via ADT. Currently, you can only work with predefined situation types using the Manage Situation Types app.

Best regards,

entry.title: Re: RV Documents not picked in F110
entry.content:
Hi @Mohamed_Shoaib ,

1. Check OBA7 for RV document type. Ensure both "D" (Customers) and "K" (Vendors) account types are allowed for RV. This is critical for netting with RV documents.
2. Verify Payment Method on RV documents: Display an RV document in FB03 and confirm a valid payment method is populated.
3. Review FBZP settings for Payment Method:
-Confirm the payment method allows both incoming and outgoing.
-Ensure "Customer/Vendor check" is active for the payment method in the company code settings.
4. F110 Additional Log Analysis: Run the proposal with the detailed log and analyze the output to pinpoint the exact reason for the RV documents being skipped. This log is your best friend in debugging F110 issues.
5. Due Dates and Payment Blocks: Confirm the RV documents are due and not blocked.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos. This motivates me to serve you better.
Appreciate your feedback.
Thanks,
Divyesh

entry.title: Auto‚Äërelease of next QM task triggered by a task completion + block manual release
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts,

I need to implement an SAP Business Workflow scenario in QM that does the following:

  1. The workflow is triggered when a QM task (BOR QMSM object) is completed.

  2. The workflow checks if there's a next task within the same quality notification.

  3. If a second task exists, the workflow should automatically release that second task.

  4. Users must not be able to manually release the second task before the first task is completed and the workflow triggers.

Could anyone guide me on:

  • How to identify and retrieve the next task of the notification in the workflow?

  • How to call the RELEASE method automatically via workflow?

  • How to prevent manual release‚Äîeither via application logic or configuration‚Äîuntil the business logic (first task completion) is satisfied?

Thanks in advance for any direction or examples!

entry.title: Benefits of Contributing to the SAP Community
entry.content:
1. Builds Your Personal Brand
    Sharing insights, answering questions, and writing blog posts showcases your expertise and positions you as a thought leader in the SAP ecosystem.

  2. Increases Visibility to Recruiters
    Many recruiters and hiring managers look for active contributors in niche communities. Your profile and contributions can make you stand out.

  3. Expands Your Network
    Engaging with others in the community can lead to connections with SAP professionals, consultants, and even hiring managers.

  4. Demonstrates Communication Skills
    Employers value candidates who can explain complex topics clearly. Your posts and answers are proof of your ability to do just that.

  5. Keeps You Updated
    Staying active in the community helps you stay current with SAP trends, tools, and best practices‚Äîsomething employers appreciate.

  6. Tips to Maximize Impact
    • Focus on High-Value Topics: Share insights on trending SAP modules (e.g., S/4HANA, BTP, Fiori, ABAP RESTful).
    • Be Consistent: Regular contributions build momentum and credibility.
    • Engage with Others: Comment on posts, ask thoughtful questions, and thank others for their insights.
    • Link to Your Work: Include your SAP Community profile on your resume and LinkedIn.

entry.title: SAP Joule for Beginners: Everything You Need to Know - All at one stop!
entry.content:
This blog is for anyone in the SAP domain ‚Äî from consultants to architects ‚Äî who is curious about SAP Joule and wants to understand how it works. You're in the right place!

Disclaimer: This blog is based on publicly available information as of 24th July 2025, along with my personal interpretation. Sources of all referenced information, where available, are quoted in the REFERENCE section of this blog.

Topics covered in this blog are:

Welcome to the world of SAP Joule! Let's decode it into chunks! 

"How can I help you? 

Talk to me naturally. For example, 'What are my task for today?"

 

This is how Joule greets you in first place!

Joule ‚Äî a name derived from the unit of energy ‚Äî is here to energize our business processes, save valuable time, and simplify even the most tedious tasks resulting in greater efficiency and a noticeable uplift in the quality of our work.

SECTION 1: Understanding key terminologies and concepts:

Let‚Äôs cover some basic artificial intelligence terms before diving deeper into Joule for better understanding.

  • Artificial intelligence (AI) is a technology that mimics human reasoning and behavior, enabling machines to make decisions on their own. By processing large volumes of data, AI can understand speech, identify patterns and trends, solve problems proactively, and forecast future outcomes.

  • GenAI also known as generative AI is a model where it can create new content which can either be text, image, audio and video based on the existing content that it already has.

  • LLM (Large language Model) is the specific model (like GPT, PaLM, LLaMA) that powers the text generation part of GenAI. It is a type of artificial intelligence model that is trained to understand and generate human-like language. It's designed to read, summarize, translate, predict, or generate text based on the input it receives. Eg, When we ask ChatGPT a question, it's an LLM that's interpreting our text and generating a relevant, natural-sounding response.

  • AI copilot is a virtual assistant that helps business application users complete tasks more easily through a conversational interface. It uses generative AI to understand requests, take actions, and offer insights from business data. AI Copilots use LLMs to understand natural language and assist users in real time.The answer that is provided to the user is limited to training data against LLMs. "Large" refers to the massive amount of data and the billions of parameters the model is trained on.

  • Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): In SAP world, customer specific data cannot be used to train the LLMs. And hence we need a better way to retrieve the desired outcomes without breaching the customer's data privacy. This is where RAG comes into picture. It is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). This is done through Document Grounding. As a part of preparation of RAG, it provided with SAP and customer specific documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are then chunked into smaller parts and are then embedded into dense, continuous vectors‚Äîknown as embeddings‚Äîwhich represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query. This information is passed to the LLM as prompts during runtime rather than getting it trained. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data. Rather, they get Grounded against customer specific data. 

  • HANA Vector Database enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords.

    Image source: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uiv29xYlXvQ

  • For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. For instance, when a user asks about their company's paternity leave policy, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.

SECTION 2: What is SAP Joule and what are its use cases in the SAP world

SAP Joule is an AI copilot from SAP. Powered by SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform), it serves as a virtual assistant that leverages generative AI to understand and respond to user requests within SAP systems.

Before diving deeper, Let's understand some of the use cases of SAP Joule. Below are some of the end-user prompts that can be sent to Joule, where it responds appropriately using natural language processing. These examples are sourced from SAP's official Joule product pages.

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html#agility-for-all

Why Joule?

Joule is SAP domain-specific and is integrated with SAP‚Äôs suite of products, ensuring seamless interaction and data exchange across the SAP portfolio. It is also a responsible AI solution, with a strong emphasis on industry-specific regulations and standards. As a result, Joule is a more Relevant, Reliable, and Responsible AI copilot for SAP.

As specified earlier, the LLMs in Joule are not actually trained to respond to SAP user queries. Instead, Joule use document grounding through RAGe (Retrieval-Augmented Generation for enterprise) for unstructured data, and the SAP Knowledge Graph for structured data, enabling it to provide more comprehensive responses by referencing business documents from both SAP and third-party repositories , while LLMs are used to add natural language rather than the actual context in the response that is sent to user by Joule. That is, Grounding uses a customer‚Äôs own knowledge sources (e.g., travel policies, enablement content, service manuals, FAQs, etc.) to supplement the capabilities of Large language models (LLMs). This gives Joule a unique understanding of SAP data and processes, allowing it to respond more reliably than any other AI copilot.

Joule is seamlessly integrated into various SAP cloud solutions to help users work more efficiently across different business functions, such as:

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud

  • SAP S/4HANA Cloud, private edition

  • SAP SuccessFactors

  • SAP Ariba

  • SAP Sales Cloud

  • SAP Customer Experience solutions

  • SAP Concur

  • SAP ABAP Cloud

However, it is worth noting that Joule is not available for on-premise solutions.

Thus the main advantages of SAP Joule include:

  • Enhanced decision-making

  • Accelerated end-to-end business processes

  • Personalized UI with inherited user authorizations

  • Advanced analytics

  • Contextual awareness

  • Ability to meet diverse business needs

Domains supported by SAP Joule:

SAP Joule runs on the AI Foundation of SAP BTP (Business Technology Platform) and supports a wide range of domains such as Finance, Procurement, Supply Chain, Human Resources, Sales and Services, Marketing and E-Commerce, Development, and Consulting.  Apart from some of the use cases described before, a detailed list of business use cases are available through URL => https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/use-cases.html

Joule's interaction pattern:

 

 

 

 

 

 

Image source: https://www.sap.com/india/products/artificial-intelligence/ai-assistant.html

Joule's interaction pattern can vary from:

  1. Informational: The Joule provides answers to factual questions (e.g. "What are the key rules for a team outing?")

  2. Navigational: The Joule guides users through a multi-step process or an internal journey, like approving a request or changing organizational data. (e.g. ‚ÄúWhere in the app do I send a promotion request?‚Äù)

  3. Transactional: The Joule engages in task completion workflows, e.g. reviewing and updating position details (job title, department, cost center), then confirming by saying ‚ÄúDone‚Äù. It also supports user edits and next steps before finalizing. (e.g. ‚ÄúUpdate the position title to Sustainability Supply Chain Consultant ‚Äî ready to submit?‚Äù)

  4. Analytical: The Joule offers data insights, metrics, and visual analytics, such as attrition trends vs. hiring rates charted by quarter. It helps users interpret numbers and trends. (e.g.‚ÄúWhat was our quarterly attrition rate in 2024?‚Äù)

SECTION 3: Joule architecture

Image source: Joule learning journey 

Joule architecture consists of key components which work together to respond to a user's question.

  1. Scenario Catalog: The Scenario Catalog holds information about all the available scenarios, functions, and skills in SAP cloud applications. In helps to distinguish between different user questions and guides Joule to understand the request and connect it to the right action or system or workflow. This acts like a blueprint that maps user queries to the appropriate actions, destinations, or logic within SAP systems. For example, if a user query is "Retrieves the current leave balance for a given employee", then this gets mapped as below:
    1. Scenario: 'Get_Employee_Leave_Balance'
    2. Domain: Human Resource
    3. 'leave balance': Employee ID, leave Type and Date Range.
  2. Knowledge Catalog: This contains SAP-knowledge as well as the customer-owned knowledge. It is a collection of documents and content sources (often unstructured or semi-structured) that are made available to Joule for question-answering using RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) techniques. It supports Joule in answering open-ended, natural language questions that aren‚Äôt directly tied to structured data or APIs. For example, it can have a company's HR policies (e.g., leave, travel, benefits), Finance guidelines (e.g., expense reimbursement rules) and so on. These documents are chunked and vectorized using embeddings in HANA vector database as specified earlier. When a user asks a related question, Joule retrieves relevant chunks and sends them to the LLM to generate a grounded answer.
  3. User Context: This helps joule to contextualize a user's question. This includes information about the SAP cloud applications the user is currently using, along with any additional SAP applications the customer has licensed and activated for use with Joule. Joule also recognizes the user‚Äôs roles and permissions, ensuring they can access only the information or perform the actions they are authorized to within the SAP cloud environment. Additionally, Joule takes into account the user‚Äôs chat history and context to provide most relevant and accurate responses to user queries. To put in other words, a user will be able to view or perform any tasks only if they are authorized to do so based on their existing authorization. 
  4. Document Grounding: Large Language Models (LLMs) are generally capable of understanding prompts and generating human-like responses. However, they often lack the context and specificity needed for business scenarios. To address this, Joule uses a technique called document grounding. This allows Joule to generate more accurate and relevant responses by referencing business documents stored in SAP and third-party repositories. As part of document grounding, customers can upload their own content (such as HR policies, travel policies, service manuals, etc.). When an end user asks a question, Joule searches these documents for relevant information and returns a concise, natural-language response, including the source references. This ensures the answers are grounded in the customer's own structured and unstructured data, making them more trustworthy and context-aware.
  5.  Grounding: This is the process of combining generative LLMs with advanced information retrieval techniques to enhance the accuracy and relevance of responses‚Äîwithout the need to train or fine-tune the model on company-specific data. It leverages a customer‚Äôs internal knowledge sources (e.g., policies, FAQs, training material) to supplement the LLM‚Äôs existing knowledge. This improves the model‚Äôs reliability and ensures that responses reflect the customer‚Äôs unique business context.
  6. Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG): RAG is used to generate more relevant answers to an SAP user's question without actually training the Large Language Model (LLM). As part of the RAG, Document Grounding is performed. In this step, RAG is provided with relevant documents such as HR policies, manuals, and SOPs that may be useful for answering SAP user queries. These documents are chunked into smaller parts and then embedded into dense, continuous vectors‚Äîknown as embeddings‚Äîwhich represent the data in a high-dimensional space. These embeddings are then stored in the HANA Vector Database for retrieval based on the user's query.
  7.  HANA Vector Database: It enables the storage, indexing, and searching of unstructured data like vector embeddings (numerical representations of text, documents, or images). This allows AI systems to retrieve and interpret information based on semantic meaning, not just keywords. For example, company policy documents are broken into chunks and converted into multi-dimensional vectors (numerical coordinates that represent the meaning of text) using an AI model. These vectors, along with metadata, are stored in the SAP HANA Vector Database to enable semantic search, so RAG can retrieve relevant content for the LLM to generate accurate natural language responses. When a user asks about their leave balance, the system converts the question into a vector, searches for the most relevant policy content using the HANA Vector Database, and then uses an LLM to generate a clear answer based on that information.
  8.  Knowledge Graph: This graph is a semantic network that connects entities (like customers, products, orders, employees, etc.) and defines how they are related. This helps Joule go beyond keyword matching or document lookup. It actually lets Joule "understand" business context and structure.  Joule uses the graph to understand how different entities are linked (e.g., ‚ÄúEmployee X belongs to Department Y‚Äù or ‚ÄúInvoice A is tied to Purchase Order B‚Äù). With this, Joule disambiguate questions and provide more accurate answers.  It also enables logical inferences, like ‚ÄúShow me all open invoices for suppliers in Germany‚Äù, ‚ÄúList products related to a delayed shipment‚Äù etc. Even if the data is spread across multiple systems, the graph can link them together efficiently.

 

 

Image sources: Knowledge Graph or Vector Database‚Ä¶ Which is Better? and  GraphRAG: The Marriage of Knowledge Graphs and RAG: Emil Eifrem

NOTE: While RAG brings in document-based context and vector search finds the right text chunks, the Knowledge Graph brings in structure and relationship-based logic. Eg: RAG may find a document about a purchase policy, but the Knowledge Graph helps determine which department owns that policy and who can approve it.

Does LLM gets trained with SAP's data?

When SAP‚Äôs AI assistant Joule interacts with a Large Language Model (LLM), it doesn‚Äôt send data for storage or training. Instead, it shares information only briefly, as part of a prompt during runtime. The LLM uses this prompt to generate a response in real time, but it doesn‚Äôt remember or learn from what it receives. Thus, LLMs are not trained against customer data.

Joule's orchestration layer:

Image source: Examining how to onboard and extend Joule | AI105

Steps involved within Joule for processing user query:

  1. User submits query in natural language via Joule client in SAP cloud apps
  2. The prompt is sent to the Dialogue Management system, which manages the conversation flow and understands the user's intent.
  3. The Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) service forms a semantic vector search query based on the user input.
  4. This query is executed against a Vector Database where document embeddings are stored. The relevant document extracts are retrieved. These embeddings were created earlier from company-specific or SAP documents using document grounding
  5. The retrieved document snippets are passed along with the original prompt to a Large Language Model. The LLM uses the relevant extracts to ground its response (ensuring the response is based on actual documents, not hallucinations).
  6. The LLM generates a natural-language answer, grounded in the retrieved documents.
  7. The final answer is displayed to the user with source links and supporting documents attached.->Example: A link to a company travel policy PDF is shown under ‚ÄúSource Document‚Äù.

For more information, refer to Provisioning and Implementing Joule learning journey 

Deep dive into SAP Joule possible workflow to respond to any user prompt

Below is a scenario which is explained in SAP joule product page specified below where a sales manager who is logged into SAP Sales Cloud, sees that there is an upcoming meeting with a customer called MDT. She takes help of joules to get below information.

Please do watch the video below which depicts Joule in action before proceeding further.

Introducing Joule - The AI copilot that truly understands your business 

USE CASE 1: Ask Joule to provide details about this customer so that she can be prepared or the meeting.

CAUTION ! The below flow is only for illustration purpose as of how Joule MIGHT respond based on my assumptions. It must be used only for understanding purpose.

USE CASE 2: She also asks Joules to extract the customer requirement by pasting the email in Joule prompt

Workflow of use case 2:  The user shares a business email requesting a product recommendation for an industrial robot. This is a semi-structured prompt. Joule extracts the requirements from this text, matches it to product data, and provides a recommendation with pricing, configuration, and confidence level.

CAUTION ! The below flow is only for illustration purpose as of how Joule MIGHT respond based on my assumptions.It must be used only for understanding purpose.

USE CASE 3: User asks Joule about the expense limit for business meals in Germany

Workflow of use case 3: 

CAUTION ! The below flow is only for illustration purpose as of how Joule MIGHT respond based on my assumptions.It must be used only for understanding purpose.

We can infer that most of the structured user queries are predominantly handled by SAP Knowledge graph while unstructured queries are handled through RAG which in turn works with HANA Vector Database.

SECTION 4: Joule packages and pricing: Base and premium

Joules comes in 2 different packages for consumption:

  1. Joule Base (No additional cost involved)
  2. Joule Premium

A. SAP Joule Base package: 

Joule Base package is available as supplement to all eligible SAP cloud subscriptions at no additional cost. As a prerequisite customer must have an active subscription to a supported SAP cloud product (e.g., SAP SuccessFactors). 

Current entitlements:

  1. Joule for developers, ABAP AI capabilities: To accelerate ABAP development with Joule
  2. Joule with SAP Fieldglass solutions: Enhance efficiencies across hiring processes with AI
  3. Joule with SAP LeanIX: Search and navigate to the right information through natural language queries.
  4. Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition: Streamline the informational, navigational, and transactional tasks.
  5. Joule with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition: Streamline the informational, navigational, and transactional tasks.

Features:

  1. Provides access to a base set of Joule‚Äôs AI functions.
  2. Supports navigation, information retrieval, and basic task assistance within SAP cloud solutions.
  3. Unlimited usage under a flat fee model.

Joule is a central service and hence customer must choose the SAP BTP global account to attach Joule to in case of base package.  For more information on this regard, please refer to links below.

  • AI Catalog - Joule Base
  • SAP Joule Base Entitlement

B. SAP Joule Premium package: 

Joule Premium enhances the Joule Base with domain-specific and agentic AI features. It is available as a paid add-on through AI Units.

Premium Packages by Domain (as on date 25th July 25):

  1. Joule Premium for financial management: Delivers deep financial insights and smart summarizations tailored for finance users. It brings in agent-driven capabilities that cover both transactional and analytical needs ‚Äî helping finance teams make better, faster decisions.
  2. Joule Premium for spend management: With features like Category Segmentation and Statement of Work (SOW) Description Generation, Joule Premium supports procurement and finance functions in improving efficiency and streamlining sourcing processes.
  3. Joule Premium for supply chain management: Enhances supply chain visibility with intelligent tools such as Equipment Insights and ESG Report Generation ‚Äî boosting transparency and operational awareness across logistics and asset-heavy processes.
  4.  Joule Premium for human capital management: HR teams can benefit from AI-Assisted Writing, Interview Feedback Insights, and other intelligent capabilities that help improve talent processes, communications, and candidate engagement.
  5. Joule Premium for customer experience: Designed to enhance customer engagement, Joule Premium in CX includes innovative features like Image Generation and Lead Booster to drive personalized interactions and improved conversions.
  6. SAP Joule for Consultants: SAP Joule empowers consultants with expert-level AI guidance, helping them accelerate SAP cloud deployments and ensure higher implementation quality and productivity.
  7. Joule for Developers: Joule acts as a real-time AI assistant for SAP developers, offering on-the-fly explanations of development objects, quick answers to dev-related queries, and seamless learning support.

Costing involved with Premium packages: AI Units

SAP Joules premium packages can be bought from the AI Catalog of Discovery center. URL:https://discovery-center.cloud.sap/ai-catalog 

These are priced based on AI Units, which serve as a virtual currency that can be used across all SAP cloud products and lines of business through a shared AI Unit pool. AI Units are calculated based on predefined business metrics (e.g., transactions, pages, users, expenses), with each metric having its own conversion rate (e.g., 1 transaction = X AI Units). 

Purchasing premium licenses typically includes a fixed number of Joule messages per year (e.g., RISE with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Premium includes approximately 2,500 messages). A single message refers to one user ask and the corresponding Joule response. Any usage beyond the included quota will consume additional AI Units.SAP provides an AI Unit Estimator Tool to help estimate AI Unit requirements based on selected capabilities and transaction volume. A quote can be requested directly through the estimator.

Below is a sample screenshot from the Discovery Center showing how to search for the package. It also displays the list of functionalities available under 'Joule Premium for Human Capital Management'. To purchase a specific functionality within this package, click on the corresponding tile to view its estimate and understand the pricing.

SECTION 5: Joule functionalities that is targeted at technology consultants

Two of the Joule premium that can help technology consultants are Joule for Consultants and Joule for developers.

A. Joule for Consultants:

SAP Joule for Consultants is a conversational AI solution that speeds up SAP cloud transformations by providing expert guidance drawn from SAP‚Äôs most extensive and carefully curated knowledge base.

Key uses:

  1. It is designed to reduce substantial amount of search time.
  2.  It helps to interpret custom code faster.
  3. It avoids rework and helps with improving the quality of work.

To enable Joule for Consultant kick start using the mission Enable SAP Joule for Consultants .

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Some of the use cases of this product as described in SAP product page at URL SAP Joule for Consultants are:

B. Joule for Developers: 

Joule for developers is part of SAP's Build portfolio. The primary objective of SAP Build is to enable citizen developers (business or end users) to build applications, processes, and business websites through visual drag-and-drop elements. It also helps professional developers accelerate development by generating data models, services, UI components, sample data, and business logic using Joule prompts.

NOTE: Joule with SAP Build is available as part of trial account or free tier. Upcoming SAP build details will have links to exercises that can be tried out with SAP BTP trial account.

Key components of SAP Build are:

  1. SAP Build Apps: SAP Build Apps helps both business users and developers quickly create and customize applications using low-code, AI assistance, and reusable modules‚Äîensuring fast, collaborative development across SAP and non-SAP systems.

  2. SAP Build Code: SAP Build Code is a powerful generative AI‚Äìbased code development environment for professional developers, offering end-to-end support for Java and JavaScript, AI-assisted coding with Joule, and a streamlined experience for collaborative SAP development across both expert and citizen developers. It provides a turnkey environment for coding, testing, integrations, and application lifecycle management.
  3. SAP Build Process Automation: SAP Build Process Automation lets both business users and developers automate workflows without coding, using drag-and-drop tools, AI, and pre-built content‚Äîboosting productivity, enabling collaboration, and running securely on SAP Business Technology Platform.
  4. SAP Build Work Zone: SAP Build Work Zone is a user-friendly platform that brings together apps, tools, and content in one place to help employees work smarter and stay informed by building digital workspaces & sites.
  5. SAP Build Content Catalog: Prebuilt business content & templates that can be reused during application build.

A. Joule and SAP Build Code:

For more information check the learning journey and git hub for sample application creation detailed steps.

entry.title: Re: Intermittent Error While Opening WWI Report in CG54
entry.content:
Hello; i assume: any WWI server has the same set up (same Winword; same WWI version)? and the local WWI version is equal to the version on genserver? Do you get problems by using "Report from template" with the same combination of GenVar/Lang?

Can you sent the document via Cg54/MAN_CALL to a recipient? (without potentially crashing WWI server farm)?

If you do a survey here regarding knwon WWI problems: a lot of consultant claim that for spec 1 it is working but not for spec 2; the reason seems to be different data structures

Therefore: can you prepare the same data in e.g. Q System and do the same? Can you generate document to "completed" in prod and it works in CG50?

What I know: with "Winword" you can prepare (in WWI template a "security" tag (e.g. document is of type internal, public, confidential). We have had many issues here.

As you may know: WWI is Winword based. On your local client may be some "security" software is checking the document etc.

In a nutshell: i can remember Consultant OSS note for "Virus handling" for WWI. May be check that

As mentioned: helpful would be: either you can reproduce the same on Q or the new generated document (with status "completed") reacts the same

Wish you the best

C.B.

entry.title: Change request created in MDG from incoming request from ARIBA does not trigger workflow
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

I have a situation where ARIBA sends request(payload) to SAP to create change request in MDG.

The service definition used is BUSINESSPARTNERSUITEBULKREPLIC.

To achieve customer specific requirement to map the correct Change request type to the Change request, I am using BADI implementation MDG_SE_BP_BULK_REPLRQ_IN~INBOUND_PROCESSING where using below code I am assigning the required CR type.

- Define internal table with type MDG_USER_PROXY_SETTING_T.
- Append Line 1

  • FIELD_NAME = "PROXY_PERSISTANCE".
  • FIELD_VALUE = "1".

- Append Line 2

  • FIELD_NAME = ‚ÄúSUPPLIER_CHANGE‚Äù
  • FIELD_VALUE = <CR Type>

- Call method: CL_MDG_BP_BUPA_SI_IN=>IF_MDG_UPLOAD_PROXY~SETUP_FOR_FILE_UPLOAD ( Exporting IV_INSTANCE = 1 IT_USER_SETTING = <Above Internal Table>  ).
After processing the request the Change request gets created successfully and can be viewed in NWBC.

But the issue is the change request that is created from this request does not trigger the necessary standard workflow for approval. Neither the CR can be edited or saved(SAVE button is disabled). Check in below screenshot the CR got created from inbound process. If you notice the CR is opened in NWBC and is in edit mode but the SAVE is disabled and also the APPROVE and REJECT button from the workflow is also missing because the workflow is not triggered as checked in the workflow log.

On the other hand, when the Change request is created manually in NWBC, there is no issue. In below screenshot, the CR is created manually and you will notice the workflow is triggered for this as I have option to approve or reject the CR. Also the Cr can be changed here and saved again.

I want to achieve this working functionality of manually created CR in the CR created from inbound process as explained in the first part. Not sure what is missing and if this could be handled through code or customizing.

Your expert opinion is needed here.

Thanks,

Sparsh

entry.title: Re: SAP Mobile Start via SAP Start Booster ‚Äì No Apps or P...
entry.content:
Hello @Vijjusk  @adnanmaqbool 

If you're seeing "Currently, there aren't any products for you" after setting up SAP Start (Foundation Plan), it‚Äôs because no content or roles have been assigned to your user.

The Foundation Plan includes trust and connectivity but does not support content federation or Launchpad Content Manager, so that apps won‚Äôt appear automatically.

To resolve this,

  • It is recommended to upgrade to SAP Build Work Zone ‚Äì Standard Plan to enable content federation and proper role-based access.
  •  Possible workaround is to manually create tiles with app URLs ‚Äî not scalable for production use

Explaining the Architecture of SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone: Frequently asked Questions

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Recalculation in termination for the whole year with...
entry.content:
Yes this is the current situation . The termination rule is called only for terminated month.

I can see the below options:

1.  Import TMRE (Time management recalculation event ) from a particular date Say April. This will ensure that the accrual recalculation is called each month after april. The termination workflow could notify a time admin who does this from MDF Import or you could schedule automated imports of TMRE on a regular basis for this employee group via MDF import by placing files in SFTP.  https://userapps.support.sap.com/sap/support/knowledge/en/3598136 . Please note if you plan to automate TMRE imports, it will run for all employees (the employees mentioned in the file) and not just the terminated employee. Hence please ensure that this method is used only where the company has relatively less employees < 2k for example. Else the time admin has to do it manually 

2. I am not 100% sure of this option..Just an idea because I have heard partners doing this. If you have CPI or BTP, You can perhaps do the following. Use intelligent services on Job Info termination event to call Integration Center. And from Integration center/or IS itself you can call an CPI Iflow. In the custom CPI iflow, you would get the payload with affected terminated user. Use this detail to create a file only for that user with TMRE event in SFTP server (similar to idea 1.). And then the MDF import picks this file from SFTP and imports the TMRE.

Regards

Neelesh

entry.title: Re: S/4HANA Product Compliance - Dangerous Goods Management
entry.content:
Hello

1.) if you are using On Prem 2023 version => it is strongly recommended to do an upgrade if the new version 2025 is released

2.) if you are using a "cloud" versioN: the same is true. Try to stay "current" with the software

Coming back to your questions and reading between the lines:

We have in SAP two main option to "pack" (according to my understanding). You pack via "production order" or via "delivery"

Now the product compliance process has a "totally" different design than EHS classic.

The main focus topic is the "material" and how it is used in the process.

I have not checked in detail: but step one would be: you try to sell a "material". Now you have an "Issue". Because the concept of "packed" / "unpacked" is (from my point of view) "strange" in PC:

Example: if you sell material via "tank ship" we call that a "bulk transport". But according to best knowledge: In PC you must handled this material as "packed" if you would like to use the "full" integration.

Let us assume this: you have a materia called "EasyClean". this you produce. Now you have two options:

Either you store that in a "tank" or you "pack" it in e.g. 1 l plastic bottle. For the later case: You have clearly now a "packed" material. So then you should handled this as "packed" material in "PC"

In a nutshell: if we talk about material which are "sold" regularly: > 90% of the companies (which i know)  have a specific "set" how they sell the material; e.g. 250 ml bottle, 500 mlg bottle and whatsoever.

In such cases: it makes sense to make the "DG classification" upfront

I strictly recommend to check the "roadmap" explorer to get insight which functionally will come in "cloud" or "on prem".

But if you need details: please get in touch with SAP direct, They can explain the best what is supported now and will be supported in e.g. on prem version 2025

Wish you the best

C.B.

  association [1..1] to A_ProcessOrder             as _ProcessOrder   on  $projection.ManufacturingOrder = _ProcessOrder.ProcessOrder
  {
  @ObjectModel.sapObjectNodeTypeReference: 'ProductionOrder'
  key cast(_Status.ManufacturingOrder      as co_bid preserving type) as ManufacturingOrder,     
  key _Status.StatusCode,
      // Status  
      cast (case when _Status.StatusCode like 'E%' then 'X' else '' end as vdm_j_isuserstatus) as IsUserStatus, 
      
      cast( case 
         when _UserStatusText.UserStatus is null then _Status.SystemStatusShortName else _UserStatusText.UserStatusShortName
         end as j_txt04 preserving type )          as StatusShortName,                                                     
         
      cast(case 
        when _UserStatusText.UserStatus is null then _Status.SystemStatusName else _UserStatusText.UserStatusName        
        end as j_txt30 preserving type )           as StatusName,                                                                                                        
        _ProcessOrder
                
}

entry.content:
Hi SAP Experts,

I'm trying to load LOCATION master data from SAP Integration Suite (CPI) to SAP IBP using the IBP Write API.

In my integration flow, I first create the batch using this payload:

Then I use a Groovy script to convert CSV to JSON and wrap it in the following payload:

However, I get the following error:
javax.script.ScriptException: java.lang.Exception: java.lang.Exception: At least one IBP Write Batch could not be created.

I have verified:

  • BatchKey is the same in both steps.

  • CSV structure and field names are correct.

Can someone help me understand why the batch creation might be failing? How can I trace this better or fix it?

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: Extended situation handling issues on SAP S/4HANA 202...
entry.content:
Hello @Lakshmipathi , @axel_spriestersbach 

hope you're doing well.

As recommended by Mr. @Lakshmipathi , I explored the scenario based on batch job execution, which initially  worked correctly. During this process, I identified the technical job SIT2_RT_BATCH as a potential solution to schedule our custom situation type to run every 30 minutes (or more frequently).

I attempted to configure and run this job, but unfortunately, it runs without detecting any active situation type ‚Äì even when a valid instance exists.

Here are the steps I followed (as per SAP standard documentation on the Help Portal):

  1. ‚úÖ Maintained the required authorizations and generated a profile for the role SAP_CA_SITN_ENGINE_WF

  2. ‚úÖ Assigned this role to the technical user SAP_WFRT(See Capture 2)

  3. ‚úÖ Maintained this user in transaction SJOBREPO_STEPUSER (See Capture 3)

  4. ‚úÖ Scheduled the job using transaction SJOBREPO, setting it to run every 1 minute

  5. After that, I checked the SIT2_RT_BATCH logs:

     

  • The job is executing every minute as expected by the technical user SAP_WFRT .

  • However, no situation type is detected ‚Äì despite having relevant data. ( see capture ) 

  • My question :

Is there something I‚Äôm missing in the configuration that prevents the job from consistently detecting the active situation type and generating notifications when instances exist?

Any insights or guidance would be highly appreciated.

Thank you in advance for your support!

Mben!!
